definitions.definition: To assert or announce formally , officially , explicitly , or emphatically .
To inform government customs or taxation officials of goods one is importing or of income , expenses , or other circumstances affecting one's taxes.
To show one's cards in order to score.
For a constituency in an election to officially announce the result
examples: Houghton and Sunderland South was the first constituency to declare in the 2015 general election.

definitions.definition: The decision of the captain to let the bowling side bat in test cricket to save time without being all out.
To explicitly establish the existence of (a variable , function , etc.) without necessarily describing its content.
examples: The counter "i" was declared as an integer.

definitions.definition: To state that a thing shall happen or affirm a condition in the hopes of seeing it happen spiritually, in contrast to prayer which takes the form of a request.
examples: He prayed to God "please heal my sister", while she declared "I am healed in Jesus' name".

main_definition: ( obsolete , transitive ) To make clear, explain , interpret .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , intransitive ) To assert or announce formally , officially , explicitly , or emphatically .
( transitive ) To inform government customs or taxation officials of goods one is importing or of income , expenses , or other circumstances affecting one's taxes.
( card games ) To show one's cards in order to score.
( intransitive , politics ) For a constituency in an election to officially announce the result
( cricket ) The decision of the captain to let the bowling side bat in test cricket to save time without being all out.
( transitive , programming ) To explicitly establish the existence of (a variable , function , etc.) without necessarily describing its content.
( grand strategy games , slang ) to declare war [ with on ]

( Christianity , particularly Evangelicalism ) To state that a thing shall happen or affirm a condition in the hopes of seeing it happen spiritually, in contrast to prayer which takes the form of a request.
